curated_list.fact: The promenade connects Crown Casino to the Arts Centre. The Evan Walker Bridge offers great city views.

curated_list.name: St Kilda Beach
curated_list.description: Melbourne's most famous beach. The pier, funky Luna Park, and a colony of little penguins at sunset.
curated_list.fact: The penguins arrive at dusk from September to March. Volunteers from Earthcare protect them.

curated_list.name: South Bank Parklands
curated_list.description: Brisbane's inner-city oasis—a man-made beach, lush gardens, and the Wheel of Brisbane. Streets Beach is free.
curated_list.fact: The park was built for World Expo '88. The Nepal Peace Pagoda remains from the expo.

curated_list.name: GOMA
curated_list.description: The Gallery of Modern Art, Australia's largest gallery of modern and contemporary art. Rotating exhibitions and a free collection.
curated_list.fact: GOMA opened in 2006. The building's water wall and black facade are iconic. The children's art centre is fantastic.

curated_list.name: Queensland Museum
curated_list.description: Natural history and science exhibits, including dinosaur fossils and the giant squid. The SparkLab is hands-on for kids.
curated_list.fact: The museum houses the state's largest collection of Queensland fossils. The Discovery Centre lets you touch specimens.

curated_list.name: Story Bridge
curated_list.description: A steel cantilever bridge completed in 1940. Climb it for panoramic city views, or walk across for free.
curated_list.fact: The bridge is one of the few in the world you can climb. The Kangaroo Point cliffs under the bridge are a climbing spot.

curated_list.name: Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary
curated_list.description: The world's oldest and largest koala sanctuary. Hold a koala, hand-feed kangaroos, and see platypuses.
curated_list.fact: Opened in 1927, the sanctuary was the first to allow koala cuddling. The new platypus exhibit is excellent.

curated_list.name: Mount Coot-tha Lookout
curated_list.description: Brisbane's best view, 287 meters above the city. The lookout is free, and the cafe serves decent coffee.
curated_list.fact: The mountain was a traditional meeting place for the Turrbal people. The botanical gardens at the base are lovely.

curated_list.name: Roma Street Parkland
curated_list.description: The world's largest subtropical garden in a city center. Waterfalls, lakes, and themed gardens on 16 hectares.
curated_list.fact: The parkland was built on a former railway yard. The Spectacle Garden has seasonal flower displays.

curated_list.name: QUT Art Museum
curated_list.description: Contemporary Australian art in a striking riverside building. The William Robinson Gallery is a highlight.
curated_list.fact: William Robinson won the Archibald Prize three times. The museum's cafe has river views.

curated_list.name: Kangaroo Point Cliffs
curated_list.description: A riverside park with dramatic cliffs, popular for rock climbing and abseiling. The boardwalk leads to the Story Bridge.
curated_list.fact: The cliffs are a volcanic formation. The park has free electric BBQs and great city views.

curated_list.name: West End
curated_list.description: Brisbane's bohemian heart—multicultural, artsy, and food-obsessed. Vintage shops, street art, and diverse restaurants.
curated_list.fact: The West End markets are on Saturday. The Vietnamese and Middle Eastern food scene is exceptional.

curated_list.name: Kings Park and Botanic Garden
curated_list.description: One of the world's largest inner-city parks, bigger than Central Park. Stunning views of the city and Swan River.
curated_list.fact: The Lotterywest Federation Walkway is a glass bridge through the treetops. The park has 3,000 species of WA flora.

curated_list.name: The Perth Mint
curated_list.description: One of the world's oldest mints still operating. See gold poured and hold a solid gold bar worth hundreds of thousands.
curated_list.fact: The mint opened in 1899. The gold bar you can hold is 400 ounces—worth over $800,000 AUD.

curated_list.name: Rottnest Island
curated_list.description: A car-free island paradise with 63 beaches. Home to the quokka, the world's happiest animal. Ferry from Perth.
curated_list.fact: Quokkas are famous for selfies—they're friendly and photogenic. The island has 20 km of bike trails.

curated_list.name: Fremantle Prison
curated_list.description: A UNESCO World Heritage convict site, operating from 1855 to 1991. Tunnel tours, eerie cell blocks, and ghost stories.
curated_list.fact: The prison is one of the most haunted sites in Australia. The torchlight tour is genuinely creepy.

curated_list.name: Cottesloe Beach
curated_list.description: Perth's most iconic beach—white sand, turquoise water, and the Indiana Teahouse. Sunsets are legendary.
curated_list.fact: The Sculpture by the Sea exhibition in March lines the coast. The Norfolk pines are heritage-listed.

curated_list.name: Fremantle Markets
curated_list.description: A historic market hall built in 1897. 150 stalls selling local produce, crafts, and food. Weekend only.
curated_list.fact: The building is a heritage site. The market has been operating for over 120 years.

curated_list.name: Art Gallery of Western Australia
curated_list.description: WA's premier art gallery, with an excellent Indigenous art collection. The building itself is a heritage landmark.
curated_list.fact: The collection includes works by Albert Namatjira. The gallery opened in 1895.

curated_list.name: Elizabeth Quay
curated_list.description: A waterfront development on the Swan River. Restaurants, bars, public art, and the iconic Spanda sculpture.
curated_list.fact: The quay was opened in 2016. The bell tower and Swan Bells are nearby.

curated_list.name: Swan Valley
curated_list.description: Perth's wine region, just 20 minutes from the city. Over 40 wineries, breweries, and distilleries.
curated_list.fact: The valley is one of Australia's oldest wine regions. The Swan Valley Cuddly Animal Farm is a hit with kids.

curated_list.name: AQWA
curated_list.description: The Aquarium of Western Australia, with the longest underwater tunnel in Australia. Sharks, rays, and turtles swim overhead.
curated_list.fact: The tunnel is 98 meters long. The aquarium focuses on WA's diverse marine life, from coral reefs to shipwrecks.

curated_list.name: Adelaide Botanic Garden
curated_list.description: A 51-hectare garden with the stunning Bicentennial Conservatory and a glasshouse of tropical plants.
curated_list.fact: The conservatory is one of the largest single-span glasshouses in the world. The Santos Museum of Economic Botany is unique.

curated_list.name: Art Gallery of South Australia
curated_list.description: One of Australia's finest art galleries, with a strong collection of Indigenous art and European masters.
curated_list.fact: The gallery has a dedicated gallery for Indigenous Australian art. The Melrose Wing opened in 2018.

curated_list.name: South Australian Museum
curated_list.description: A natural history museum with an outstanding collection of Australian Aboriginal artifacts and a massive whale skeleton.
curated_list.fact: The museum has the world's largest collection of Australian Aboriginal cultural material. The giant squid is a highlight.

curated_list.name: Glenelg Beach
curated_list.description: Adelaide's most popular beach, connected to the city by tram. Jetty, cafes, and sunset views.
curated_list.fact: The tram to Glenelg is heritage-listed. The Beachhouse has an aquarium and amusement rides.

curated_list.name: Adelaide Zoo
curated_list.description: Australia's second-oldest zoo, home to Wang Wang and Funi, the only giant pandas in the Southern Hemisphere.
curated_list.fact: The zoo opened in 1883. The pandas' arrival in 2009 was a major diplomatic event.

curated_list.name: Hahndorf
curated_list.description: Australia's oldest surviving German settlement, 20 minutes from Adelaide. Half-timbered houses, bakeries, and pubs.
curated_list.fact: The Hahndorf Inn has been serving beer since 1863. The German bakeries sell authentic pretzels and strudel.

curated_list.name: National Railway Museum
curated_list.description: The largest railway museum in Australia. Over 100 exhibits, including locomotives and carriages you can climb into.
curated_list.fact: The museum has a working turntable and operates train rides on some days. The collection spans 1850 to present.

curated_list.name: Port Adelaide
curated_list.description: A historic port district with maritime museums, galleries, and pubs. The dolphin sanctuary is nearby.
curated_list.fact: The lighthouse was built in 1869. The town has been used as a filming location for 'Wolf Creek.'

curated_list.name: Adelaide Hills
curated_list.description: A scenic region of rolling hills, wineries, and charming villages. Mount Lofty Summit offers panoramic views.
curated_list.fact: The Cleland Wildlife Park lets you get close to kangaroos and koalas. The region produces excellent cool-climate wines.

curated_list.name: Barossa Valley
curated_list.description: One of Australia's most famous wine regions, just an hour from Adelaide. Shiraz is king here.
curated_list.fact: The Barossa is home to some of the world's oldest Shiraz vines, planted in the 1840s. Penfolds and Henschke are legendary.

curated_list.name: Buckingham Palace
curated_list.description: The official residence of the British monarch. The State Rooms are open to the public in summer.
curated_list.fact: The palace has 775 rooms, including 19 State Rooms. The Changing of the Guard is a daily spectacle.

curated_list.name: British Museum
curated_list.description: One of the world's greatest museums, housing the Rosetta Stone, Parthenon marbles, and Egyptian mummies.
curated_list.fact: The museum has over 8 million objects. The Great Court roof is the largest covered public square in Europe.

curated_list.name: Tate Modern
curated_list.description: Modern art in a former power station. The Turbine Hall hosts massive installations. Free collection.
curated_list.fact: The building's iconic chimney is 99 meters tall. The Switch House offers 360-degree city views.

curated_list.name: Natural History Museum
curated_list.description: A cathedral of science in a stunning Romanesque building. Dinosaurs, mammals, and the 30-meter blue whale skeleton.
curated_list.fact: The building's terracotta facade is decorated with animals. Hintze Hall is dominated by 'Hope,' the blue whale.

curated_list.name: London Eye
curated_list.description: A giant Ferris wheel on the South Bank. 30-minute rotation offers panoramic views of London's landmarks.
curated_list.fact: The Eye has 32 capsules, each weighing 10 tons. On clear days, you can see 40km in every direction.

curated_list.name: Warwick Castle
curated_list.description: A medieval castle with a 1,000-year history, complete with towers, dungeons, and falconry displays.
curated_list.fact: The castle was fortified by William the Conqueror in 1068. The trebuchet is one of the world's largest working siege engines.

curated_list.name: Edinburgh Castle
curated_list.description: A fortress perched on an extinct volcano, dominating the Edinburgh skyline. Home to the Crown Jewels of Scotland.
curated_list.fact: The castle has been a royal residence since the 12th century. The One o'Clock Gun is fired daily.

curated_list.name: National Museum of Scotland
curated_list.description: A fascinating museum covering Scottish history, natural world, and global cultures. The rooftop terrace offers city views.
curated_list.fact: The museum's Victorian building and modern extension are seamlessly connected. Dolly the sheep is on display.

curated_list.name: Conwy Castle
curated_list.description: A masterpiece of medieval military architecture, built by Edward I. The walled town is perfectly preserved.
curated_list.fact: The castle was built in just four years (1283-1287). You can walk the entire circuit of town walls.

curated_list.name: Cairngorms National Park
curated_list.description: The UK's largest national park, with mountains, forests, and the chance to see reindeer and golden eagles.
curated_list.fact: The Cairngorms are home to the only free-ranging reindeer herd in the UK. The park has five of Scotland's six highest peaks.

curated_list.name: Giant's Causeway
curated_list.description: A UNESCO site of 40,000 hexagonal basalt columns formed by volcanic activity. Legend says a giant built it.
curated_list.fact: The columns were formed 60 million years ago. The Organ and the Wishing Chair are famous formations.

curated_list.name: Cardiff Castle
curated_list.description: A Roman fort turned Norman keep turned Victorian Gothic mansion. The interiors are wildly ornate.
curated_list.fact: The third Marquess of Bute, the richest man in the world at the time, commissioned the Gothic revival interiors.

curated_list.name: York Minster
curated_list.description: One of the largest Gothic cathedrals in Northern Europe. The Great East Window is the size of a tennis court.
curated_list.fact: The cathedral took 250 years to build. The central tower offers panoramic views of the city.

curated_list.name: Lake District National Park
curated_list.description: England's largest national park, with stunning lakes, mountains, and literary heritage (Wordsworth, Beatrix Potter).
curated_list.fact: Scafell Pike, England's highest mountain, is here. Derwentwater is one of the most beautiful lakes.

curated_list.name: Culloden Battlefield
curated_list.description: The site of the last battle on British soil (1746). A moving memorial to the Jacobite cause. Leanach Cottage is original.
curated_list.fact: The battle lasted less than an hour. The clan graves are marked with simple stones.

curated_list.name: Louvre Museum
curated_list.description: The world's largest art museum, housed in a former royal palace. Mona Lisa, Venus de Milo, and Winged Victory.
curated_list.fact: The museum has over 35,000 works on display. The Louvre Pyramid was controversial when built in 1989.

curated_list.name: Eiffel Tower
curated_list.description: The symbol of Paris. Gustave Eiffel's 330-meter iron lattice tower. Elevator or stairs to the top.
curated_list.fact: The tower was originally meant to be temporary. It has a champagne bar at the top.

curated_list.name: Arc de Triomphe
curated_list.description: Napoleon's triumphal arch, at the center of Place de l'Étoile. Climb for views down the Champs-Élysées.
curated_list.fact: The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier lies beneath. The flame is rekindled daily.

curated_list.name: Notre-Dame Cathedral
curated_list.description: A masterpiece of Gothic architecture, reopened in December 2024 after the devastating fire. The spire is rebuilt.
curated_list.fact: The 2019 fire destroyed the roof and spire. The five-year restoration was one of the most complex in history.

curated_list.name: Palace of Versailles
curated_list.description: The opulent palace of Louis XIV. The Hall of Mirrors, royal apartments, and 800 hectares of gardens.
curated_list.fact: The palace has 2,300 rooms. The gardens have 50 fountains, which operate on musical weekends.

curated_list.name: Bassins de Lumières
curated_list.description: A digital art center in a WWII submarine base. Massive projections of Klimt, Van Gogh, and other artists fill the space.
curated_list.fact: The bunker was built by the Germans in 1943. It's the largest digital art center in the world.

curated_list.name: Les Carrières de Lumières
curated_list.description: A former quarry transformed into an immersive art space. Giant projections cover the rock walls.
curated_list.fact: The quarry has been used since Roman times. The sound and light shows are breathtaking.

curated_list.name: Palais des Papes
curated_list.description: One of the largest Gothic palaces in Europe, where popes lived in the 14th century. The walls are massive.
curated_list.fact: The palace is 15,000 square meters. The Tour de la Garde offers views of the Rhône and the famous bridge.

curated_list.name: Mer de Glace
curated_list.description: France's largest glacier, accessible by a cogwheel train from Chamonix. Ice caves are carved into the glacier.
curated_list.fact: The glacier has retreated dramatically—you descend more than 700 steps to reach the ice cave.

curated_list.name: Val Thorens
curated_list.description: Europe's highest ski resort at 2,300 meters. Part of the Three Valleys, the world's largest ski area.
curated_list.fact: The resort is purpose-built and car-free. Summer skiing is possible on the glaciers.

curated_list.name: Musée Unterlinden
curated_list.description: A stunning museum in a former Dominican convent, home to the Issenheim Altarpiece, Grünewald's masterpiece.
curated_list.fact: The museum reopened in 2015 with a new wing by Herzog & de Meuron. The altarpiece is a Renaissance treasure.

curated_list.name: Château de Tonquédec
curated_list.description: A 12th-century castle in Brittany, partially in ruins and wonderfully atmospheric. Wander the grounds for free.
curated_list.fact: The castle was partially dismantled in the 17th century by Richelieu. The grounds are perfect for picnics.

curated_list.name: Colline du Château
curated_list.description: A hilltop park with panoramic views of Nice and the Baie des Anges. The waterfall is a highlight.
curated_list.fact: The castle was destroyed in 1706. The elevator saves the climb up 200 steps.

curated_list.name: Lourmarin
curated_list.description: One of the most beautiful villages in France. A Renaissance château, winding streets, and markets.
curated_list.fact: Albert Camus is buried here. The village is a favorite of artists and writers.

curated_list.name: Château de Chambord
curated_list.description: The largest castle in the Loire Valley, a Renaissance masterpiece with a double-helix staircase attributed to Leonardo.
curated_list.fact: The castle has 440 rooms and 365 fireplaces. The rooftop terrace is a fantasy of chimneys.

curated_list.name: Colosseum
curated_list.description: The iconic Roman amphitheater, completed in 80 AD. Gladiator battles and spectacles for 50,000 spectators.
curated_list.fact: The Colosseum had 80 entrances and could be emptied in 15 minutes. The hypogeum (underground) is now open.

curated_list.name: Vatican Museums
curated_list.description: One of the world's greatest art collections. The Sistine Chapel ceiling by Michelangelo is the highlight.
curated_list.fact: The museums have over 70,000 works, 20,000 on display. The spiral staircase is a masterpiece.

curated_list.name: Uffizi Gallery
curated_list.description: One of the world's finest art museums, with Botticelli's Birth of Venus, Leonardo's Annunciation, and Raphael's Madonnas.
curated_list.fact: The museum was originally the Medici family's offices. The Vasari Corridor connects it to the Pitti Palace.

curated_list.name: Galleria dell'Accademia
curated_list.description: Home to Michelangelo's David, the most famous sculpture in the world. Four unfinished Slaves are also here.
curated_list.fact: David was carved from a single block of marble discarded by other artists. The museum is small, so book ahead.

curated_list.name: Piazza San Marco
curated_list.description: Napoleon called it 'the drawing room of Europe.' St. Mark's Basilica, the Campanile, and the Doge's Palace.
curated_list.fact: The basilica's horses are copies—the originals are inside. The Campanile collapsed in 1902 and was rebuilt.

curated_list.name: Rialto Bridge
curated_list.description: Venice's most famous bridge, lined with shops. The view from the Grand Canal is postcard-perfect.
curated_list.fact: The current bridge dates to 1591. The Rialto Market has been here for over 1,000 years.

curated_list.name: Pompeii
curated_list.description: The ancient Roman city frozen in time by Vesuvius in 79 AD. Wander streets, houses, and the amphitheater.
curated_list.fact: The city was buried under 4-6 meters of ash. Only 75% has been excavated. Plaster casts show the victims.

curated_list.name: Mount Vesuvius
curated_list.description: The volcano that destroyed Pompeii. Hike to the crater for views of the Bay of Naples and steam vents.
curated_list.fact: Vesuvius is the only active volcano on the European mainland. The last eruption was in 1944.

curated_list.name: Amalfi Coast
curated_list.description: A stunning stretch of coastline with colorful villages clinging to cliffs. The Path of the Gods hike is unforgettable.
curated_list.fact: The coast is a UNESCO site. Positano has no roads—just stairs. The lemon groves produce limoncello.

curated_list.name: Duomo di Siena
curated_list.description: A Gothic masterpiece with black and white striped marble. The Piccolomini Library is covered in frescoes.
curated_list.fact: The floor is inlaid marble with scenes from 56 artists. The planned expansion was abandoned after the plague.

curated_list.name: Mosaics of Ravenna
curated_list.description: Eight UNESCO sites with breathtaking Byzantine mosaics. San Vitale and Galla Placidia are the highlights.
curated_list.fact: The mosaics date from the 5th and 6th centuries. Emperor Justinian's portrait is in San Vitale.

curated_list.name: Mole Antonelliana
curated_list.description: Turin's iconic landmark, housing the National Museum of Cinema. The panoramic elevator offers city views.
curated_list.fact: The building was originally a synagogue. The spire is 167 meters tall, visible from everywhere.

curated_list.name: The Last Supper
curated_list.description: Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece in the refectory of Santa Maria delle Grazie. Booking is essential months ahead.
curated_list.fact: The painting began deteriorating immediately due to Leonardo's experimental technique. It's been restored multiple times.

curated_list.name: Arena di Verona
curated_list.description: A Roman amphitheater from 30 AD, still in use for opera performances. The summer festival is world-famous.
curated_list.fact: The arena holds 15,000 spectators. The original outer wall was destroyed in an earthquake in 1117.

curated_list.name: Leaning Tower of Pisa
curated_list.description: The famous bell tower that leans due to unstable ground. Climb the 294 steps for a tilted view.
curated_list.fact: The lean is now 4 degrees, reduced from 5.5 degrees after stabilization work in the 1990s.

curated_list.name: Sagrada Família
curated_list.description: Gaudí's unfinished masterpiece, a UNESCO site. The Nativity façade and the interior forest of columns are breathtaking.
curated_list.fact: Construction began in 1882 and is expected to finish in 2026, the centenary of Gaudí's death.

curated_list.name: Park Güell
curated_list.description: Gaudí's whimsical park with mosaic lizards, the serpentine bench, and stunning city views.
curated_list.fact: The park was originally a failed housing development. The caretaker's house is now a museum.

curated_list.name: Prado Museum
curated_list.description: One of the world's finest art museums, with masterpieces by Velázquez, Goya, and El Greco.
curated_list.fact: The museum has 8,000 paintings, with 1,500 on display. Las Meninas is the star attraction.

curated_list.name: Royal Palace of Madrid
curated_list.description: The official residence of the Spanish royal family, used for state ceremonies. The throne room is opulent.
curated_list.fact: The palace has 3,418 rooms. The Armory holds one of the world's finest collections of weapons.

curated_list.name: Royal Alcázar of Seville
curated_list.description: A stunning Moorish palace still used by the royal family. The gardens and the Palace of Pedro I are highlights.
curated_list.fact: The Alcázar was used as a filming location for Game of Thrones (the Water Gardens of Dorne).

curated_list.name: Seville Cathedral
curated_list.description: The largest Gothic cathedral in the world, built on the site of a mosque. The Giralda tower offers views.
curated_list.fact: Christopher Columbus's tomb is here, carried by four kings. The cathedral has 80 chapels.

curated_list.name: Alhambra
curated_list.description: A stunning Moorish palace and fortress complex, with intricate tilework, fountains, and the Generalife gardens.
curated_list.fact: The Nasrid Palaces are the highlight—book months ahead. The complex is one of Spain's most visited sites.

curated_list.name: Aljafería Palace
curated_list.description: A Moorish fortress-palace from the 11th century, later used as a royal residence. The Islamic art is exquisite.
curated_list.fact: The palace is home to the Cortes of Aragon. The Golden Hall is the most beautiful room.

curated_list.name: Catedral de Mallorca
curated_list.description: A stunning Gothic cathedral on the waterfront, with a rose window the size of a small building.
curated_list.fact: Gaudí worked on the restoration in the early 20th century. The wrought iron baldachin is his design.

curated_list.name: Teide National Park
curated_list.description: Spain's highest peak (3,718 meters) and a UNESCO World Heritage site. The landscape is volcanic and lunar.
curated_list.fact: The cable car takes you to 3,555 meters. A permit is required for the final climb to the summit.

curated_list.name: Guggenheim Museum Bilbao
curated_list.description: Frank Gehry's titanium masterpiece that transformed Bilbao. The architecture is the star, with contemporary art inside.
curated_list.fact: The museum's 'Puppy' (a floral sculpture) is by Jeff Koons. The building's curves reflect the river.

curated_list.name: Cuevas de Altamira
curated_list.description: The 'Sistine Chapel of Paleolithic Art,' with 20,000-year-old bison and deer paintings. The replica is accessible.
curated_list.fact: The original cave is closed to the public to preserve it. The replica in the museum is incredibly accurate.

curated_list.name: Brandenburg Gate
curated_list.description: Berlin's iconic landmark and symbol of German reunification. The Quadriga chariot crowns the 18th-century gate.
curated_list.fact: The gate was closed during the Cold War in the no-man's land. It reopened when the Wall fell in 1989.

curated_list.name: Reichstag Building
curated_list.description: The German parliament building with Norman Foster's glass dome. Climb the dome for 360° city views.
curated_list.fact: The dome is open to the public free of charge but requires registration. The mirrored cone reflects light into the chamber.

curated_list.name: Museum Island
curated_list.description: A UNESCO site with five world-class museums. The Pergamon Altar and Nefertiti bust are highlights.
curated_list.fact: The Pergamon Museum houses the Ishtar Gate. The Neues Museum has the iconic Egyptian queen's bust.

curated_list.name: Neuschwanstein Castle
curated_list.description: The fairy-tale castle that inspired Disney's. Built by Ludwig II, it's a 19th-century Romanesque fantasy.
curated_list.fact: The castle was intended as a personal refuge—Ludwig only lived here for 170 days. The throne room is breathtaking.

curated_list.name: Marienplatz
curated_list.description: Munich's central square, with the New Town Hall's Glockenspiel performance daily. The Old Town Hall is also here.
curated_list.fact: The Glockenspiel reenacts two 16th-century stories. The Viktualienmarkt food market is nearby.

curated_list.name: Cologne Cathedral
curated_list.description: A Gothic masterpiece and UNESCO site. The twin spires dominate the skyline. The Shrine of the Magi is inside.
curated_list.fact: Construction began in 1248 and wasn't finished until 1880. The cathedral survived WWII bombing despite being hit.

curated_list.name: Römer
curated_list.description: Frankfurt's historic city hall with its iconic stepped gables. The Römerberg square is beautifully reconstructed.
curated_list.fact: The complex has been the town hall for 600 years. It was rebuilt after WWII destruction.

curated_list.name: Berchtesgaden National Park
curated_list.description: A stunning alpine park with Germany's second-highest peak, the Watzmann. The Königssee lake is emerald green.
curated_list.fact: The Königssee is so clean you can drink from it. The boat ride to St. Bartholomä church is iconic.

curated_list.name: Moselle Valley
curated_list.description: A picturesque valley of vineyards, castles, and winding river. The Reichsburg Castle in Cochem is a highlight.
curated_list.fact: The Moselle is Germany's oldest wine region, dating to Roman times. Riesling is the king here.

curated_list.name: Römersteig Trail
curated_list.description: A stunning 8km trail along the Rhine Gorge, a UNESCO site. Panoramic views of the river and castles.
curated_list.fact: The trail is part of the Rheinsteig. The view from the Stahleck Castle hostel is unforgettable.

curated_list.name: Rijksmuseum
curated_list.description: The Netherlands' national museum, home to Rembrandt's Night Watch and Vermeer's Milkmaid.
curated_list.fact: The building itself is a masterpiece, reopened in 2013 after a decade-long renovation.

curated_list.name: Van Gogh Museum
curated_list.description: The world's largest collection of Van Gogh's paintings, including Sunflowers and The Potato Eaters.
curated_list.fact: The museum also has works by Gauguin and Monet. The building has two wings by Gerrit Rietveld.

curated_list.name: Anne Frank House
curated_list.description: The hiding place where Anne Frank wrote her diary during WWII. A moving and essential experience.
curated_list.fact: The bookcase hiding the annex is still there. Book months ahead—tickets sell out immediately.

curated_list.name: Rijksmuseum
curated_list.description: The Netherlands' national museum, home to Rembrandt's Night Watch and Vermeer's Milkmaid.
curated_list.fact: The building itself is a masterpiece, reopened in 2013 after a decade-long renovation.

curated_list.name: Van Gogh Museum
curated_list.description: The world's largest collection of Van Gogh's paintings, including Sunflowers and The Potato Eaters.
curated_list.fact: The museum also has works by Gauguin and Monet. The building has two wings by Gerrit Rietveld.

curated_list.name: Anne Frank House
curated_list.description: The hiding place where Anne Frank wrote her diary during WWII. A moving and essential experience.
curated_list.fact: The bookcase hiding the annex is still there. Book months ahead—tickets sell out immediately.

curated_list.name: Amsterdam Canals
curated_list.description: A UNESCO World Heritage site, the 17th-century canal ring is Amsterdam's heart. Walk, bike, or boat.
curated_list.fact: The canals form concentric half-circles around the city. There are 1,500 bridges.

curated_list.name: Keukenhof Gardens
curated_list.description: The world's largest flower garden, with 7 million bulbs blooming each spring. Open only March to May.
curated_list.fact: The park has 800 varieties of tulips. The flower parade passes through in April.

curated_list.name: Kinderdijk
curated_list.description: A UNESCO site with 19 windmills from the 18th century. The iconic Dutch landscape, still working.
curated_list.fact: The windmills were built to drain the polder. You can tour the inside of some mills.

curated_list.name: Markthal Rotterdam
curated_list.description: A stunning horseshoe-shaped market hall with a giant mural inside. Underneath, 100+ food stalls.
curated_list.fact: The mural is called 'Horn of Plenty' and is one of the largest artworks in the world.

curated_list.name: Acropolis of Athens
curated_list.description: The iconic ancient citadel with the Parthenon, Erechtheion, and Temple of Athena Nike. UNESCO site.
curated_list.fact: The Parthenon was built 447-432 BC. The new Acropolis Museum displays original sculptures.

curated_list.name: Acropolis Museum
curated_list.description: A stunning modern museum built over an archaeological excavation. The Parthenon gallery is breathtaking.
curated_list.fact: The museum opened in 2009. The glass floor allows you to see the ancient neighborhood below.

curated_list.name: Santorini
curated_list.description: The stunning caldera island with whitewashed villages, blue domes, and unforgettable sunsets.
curated_list.fact: Santorini is the site of one of the largest volcanic eruptions in history, around 1600 BC.

curated_list.name: Fira to Oia Hike
curated_list.description: A stunning 10km hike along the caldera rim from Fira to Oia. Unforgettable views of the volcano.
curated_list.fact: The hike takes 3-4 hours. Start early to avoid the midday heat.

curated_list.name: Mykonos
curated_list.description: The glamorous island of whitewashed windmills, boutique shops, and vibrant nightlife. Little Venice is iconic.
curated_list.fact: The island's windmills date to the 16th century. The pelican Petros is the mascot.

curated_list.name: Meteora
curated_list.description: UNESCO site with monasteries perched atop immense rock pillars. A place of incredible beauty and spirituality.
curated_list.fact: There were originally 24 monasteries; six are active today. The views are breathtaking.

curated_list.name: Palace of Knossos
curated_list.description: The center of Minoan civilization, associated with the myth of the Minotaur. The palace is partly reconstructed.
curated_list.fact: The site dates to 1900 BC. The frescoes are copies—the originals are in the Heraklion Museum.

curated_list.name: Rhodes Old Town
curated_list.description: The best-preserved medieval town in Europe, a UNESCO site. Walk the Street of the Knights.
curated_list.fact: The Knights of St. John built the walls in the 14th century. The Palace of the Grand Master is a fortress.

curated_list.name: Belém Tower
curated_list.description: A 16th-century fortress on the Tagus River, symbol of the Age of Discovery. UNESCO site.
curated_list.fact: The tower was built to defend Lisbon. It's a Manueline masterpiece, decorated with ropes and armillary spheres.

curated_list.name: Jerónimos Monastery
curated_list.description: A stunning Manueline monastery, UNESCO site. Vasco da Gama is buried here. The cloisters are breathtaking.
curated_list.fact: The monastery was funded by spice trade taxes. Construction began in 1501 and took 100 years.

curated_list.name: Livraria Lello
curated_list.description: One of the world's most beautiful bookstores, with a stunning Art Nouveau staircase and stained glass.
curated_list.fact: The bookstore inspired J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter. The entrance fee is deductible from book purchases.

curated_list.name: Douro Valley
curated_list.description: A UNESCO wine region of terraced vineyards along the Douro River. Port wine is the specialty.
curated_list.fact: The Douro is one of the world's oldest demarcated wine regions (1756). A river cruise is the best way to see it.

curated_list.name: Sintra
curated_list.description: A fairy-tale town of colorful palaces and castles. Pena Palace, Moorish Castle, and Quinta da Regaleira.
curated_list.fact: Sintra is a UNESCO site. The Regaleira has an inverted tower for esoteric rituals.

curated_list.name: Cabo da Roca
curated_list.description: The westernmost point of mainland Europe. Dramatic cliffs and a lighthouse. The winds are fierce.
curated_list.fact: The landmark cross quotes Camões: 'Where the land ends and the sea begins.' The views are stunning.

curated_list.name: Elephant Rock
curated_list.description: A natural rock formation on Nazare's beach that looks exactly like an elephant wading in the ocean.
curated_list.fact: Nazare is famous for giant waves (up to 30 meters). The 'elephant' is best seen from the clifftop.

curated_list.name: Lagos Caves
curated_list.description: Stunning golden cliffs and sea caves along the Algarve coast. Boat tours explore the grottos.
curated_list.fact: The Ponta da Piedade headland has hidden arches and secret beaches. Kayak for the best access.

curated_list.name: Matterhorn
curated_list.description: The world's most iconic mountain. The pyramid peak dominates Zermatt. Gornergrat railway offers stunning views.
curated_list.fact: The Matterhorn is 4,478 meters. It was first climbed in 1865—four climbers died on the descent.

curated_list.name: Jungfraujoch
curated_list.description: The Top of Europe—a train ride to 3,454 meters through the Eiger. Ice Palace and Sphinx Observatory.
curated_list.fact: The Jungfrau railway opened in 1912. The Sphinx Observatory offers 360° views of the Alps.

curated_list.name: Lake Geneva
curated_list.description: Western Europe's largest lake, with the Alps as a backdrop. Chillon Castle and Montreux jazz festival.
curated_list.fact: The lake is shaped like a crescent moon. Chillon Castle inspired Lord Byron.

curated_list.name: Oberhofen Castle
curated_list.description: A 13th-century castle on Lake Thun, with a unique tower chapel over the water. The gardens are lovely.
curated_list.fact: The castle is one of the most photographed in Switzerland. The view from the lake is stunning.

curated_list.name: Lauterbrunnen Valley
curated_list.description: A stunning valley with 72 waterfalls, including the famous Staubbach Falls. Tolkien inspiration for Rivendell.
curated_list.fact: The valley is carved by glaciers. The Trümmelbach Falls are inside the mountain.

curated_list.name: Grindelwald First
curated_list.description: A mountain adventure hub with a cliff walk, zip line, and hikes to Bachalpsee lake with Eiger views.
curated_list.fact: The First Cliff Walk is a metal walkway clinging to the cliff. The Bachalpsee reflection is iconic.

curated_list.name: Schönbrunn Palace
curated_list.description: The Habsburg summer palace, a UNESCO site. The 1,441-room Rococo masterpiece has stunning gardens.
curated_list.fact: The palace has the world's oldest zoo. The Gloriette offers panoramic city views.

curated_list.name: Belvedere Palace
curated_list.description: A Baroque palace complex housing Klimt's The Kiss. The Upper Belvedere has the main collection.
curated_list.fact: The palace was built for Prince Eugene of Savoy. The gardens are a masterpiece.

curated_list.name: St. Stephen's Cathedral
curated_list.description: Vienna's Gothic mother church, with a colorful tiled roof. The catacombs and north tower views.
curated_list.fact: The roof has 230,000 glazed tiles. The Pummerin bell is one of Europe's largest.

curated_list.name: Hohensalzburg Castle
curated_list.description: One of Europe's largest medieval castles, perched above Salzburg. The fortress has never been conquered.
curated_list.fact: The castle dates to 1077. The funicular takes you up. Views of the Alps and city are stunning.

curated_list.name: Hallstatt
curated_list.description: A picture-perfect village on Lake Hallstatt, with houses clinging to cliffs. A UNESCO site.
curated_list.fact: Hallstatt is one of the oldest inhabited places in Europe, with salt mines for 7,000 years.

curated_list.name: Grossglockner Road
curated_list.description: A stunning alpine road with 36 switchbacks, leading to Austria's highest peak. Glaciers and marmots.
curated_list.fact: The road was built in the 1930s. The Kaiser-Franz-Josefs-Höhe viewpoint is spectacular.

curated_list.name: Guinness Storehouse
curated_list.description: The home of Guinness, in a seven-story building shaped like a pint. The Gravity Bar has 360° city views.
curated_list.fact: The lease is for 9,000 years, signed in 1759. The perfect pint pour takes 119.5 seconds.

curated_list.name: Trinity College Library
curated_list.description: The Old Library houses the Book of Kells, a 9th-century illuminated manuscript. The Long Room is breathtaking.
curated_list.fact: The Long Room has 200,000 of the library's oldest books. It was a filming location for Harry Potter.

curated_list.name: Cliffs of Moher
curated_list.description: 8km of dramatic sea cliffs rising 214 meters above the Atlantic. O'Brien's Tower offers views.
curated_list.fact: The cliffs are home to 30,000 seabirds. On clear days, you can see the Aran Islands.

curated_list.name: Ring of Kerry
curated_list.description: A 179km scenic drive around the Iveragh Peninsula. Mountains, lakes, and coastal views.
curated_list.fact: The route includes Killarney National Park, Gap of Dunloe, and Muckross House.

curated_list.name: Giant's Causeway
curated_list.description: A UNESCO site of 40,000 hexagonal basalt columns. Legend says a giant built it to fight a rival.
curated_list.fact: The columns were formed 60 million years ago by volcanic activity. The Organ and the Wishing Chair are famous.

curated_list.name: The Dark Hedges
curated_list.description: An atmospheric avenue of beech trees planted in the 18th century. Famous from Game of Thrones (Kingsroad).
curated_list.fact: The trees arch over the road, creating a tunnel effect. It's a photography hotspot.
